title: Speeding drivers given choice of a time out instead of a fine
text:
The new scheme is seeking to find out whether depriving drivers of their time is better than taking away their money (Picture: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Police are offering speeding drivers the choice of either taking a break from the road or a fine.

In a bid to crack down on traffic accidents, motorists can now offer to wait in a car park instead of forking out money for their mistakes.

Under the new scheme in Estonia, motorists breaking the speed limit by 20 km an hour would have to wait 45 minutes in a car park next to the road.

This increases to 60 minutes if they’re caught driving between 21 and 40 km an hour over the limit.

The new initiative will be tested out on a road between the town of Rapla and the capital Tallinn tomorrow morning.

But only drivers with a clean driving record will be able to choose a time-out, with previous offenders automatically getting fined, reports ERR.

Only people with clean driving records will be given the option (Picture: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Police and Border Guard Board innovation adviser Elari Kasemets said: ‘We are investigating how speeders perceive the fine and the impact of the lost time.

‘We know from interviews with motorists that some people consider having a conversation with a police officer and the time they take to intervene more effective than fines.’

The scheme is expected to be trialled several times over the next two weeks.

Last year 67 people in Estonia were killed in road accidents and 1,824 were injured – a sharp rise from 2017.

description: Police in Estonia are trialing a scheme where people breaking the speed limit can either take a fine or wait for 45 or 60 minutes.
